poem:
"In Praise of Delicate Blooms" 

Tiny sighs of the careful hands,
Respite comes to the floral land.
A Chelsea show - riotous, bright,
In whispers of foliage, takes flight.
Small gardens bloom under the gaze,
Messy perfection, a silent praise.
At the close, the horticulturist's year,
In each petal, a story to hear.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "At the Chelsea flower show, foliage is in. Which bodes well for small gardens The biggest hoorah of the horticultural year is coming to an end, and if you listen closely you might hear tiny sighs of relief from the industry. The Chelsea flower show is a bun fight: glorious, indulgent, exhausting, complicated and messy in its perfection – but a huge source of inspiration for the rest of us, even those with tiny gardens.". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
